RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduação em Ecologia pela UNESP de Rio Claro, mestrado em Sensoriamento Remoto pelo INPE e doutorado em Geologia pela UNICAMP, cumprindo parte do programa no Serviço Geológico Americano (USGS). Realizou Pós-Dourado junto ao Desert Research Institute (DRI), à Universidade de Griffith, e à Universidade de Florença. Foi professor assistente do Departamento de Geociências da Universidade de Los Andes. Principais tópicos de interesse: estimativa de parâmetros de modelos numéricos de água subterrânea e parâmetros geotécnicos e hidráulicos de solo. Desenvolvimento e aplicação de métodos de análise espacial (geoestatística, processamento digital de imagem, análise multivariada, simulação estocástica e técnicas de aprendizado de máquina) para modelagem de processos erosivos em vertentes e bancos marginais.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Graduated in Ecology at Sao Paulo State University (UNESP), has a Master's degree in Remote Sensing from Brazil's National Institute for Space Research (INPE), and a Ph.D. in Geosciences from Campinas University (UNICAMP). As part of his doctoral studies, he worked as a visiting scientist at the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). Recently, he worked as a post-doctoral researcher at the Desert Research Institute (DRI) and as a research Fellow at the Australian Rivers Institute (ARI), Griffith University. His research interests are concentrated on applications of spatial analysis methods (geostatistics, digital image processing, multivariate analysis, stochastic simulation and machine learning techniques) to investigate soil properties and its interaction with surface and groundwater.

GRADUACAO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-DE-CONCLUSAO-DE-CURSO: Uso do MATLAB na análise espacial de nutrientes presentes no solo do Parque Estadual da Ilha do Cardoso/SP

DOUTORADO.TITULO-DA-DISSERTACAO-TESE: Modeling of soil weathering on hillslopes: coping with nonlinearity and coupled processes using a data-driven approach
DOUTORADO.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-ORIENTADOR: Carlos Roberto de Souza Filho e Michael James Friedel

POS-DOUTORADO.NOME-AGENCIA: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico

Docência Parcial - Introdução ao Sensoriamento Remoto

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Modeling of soil weathering on hillslopes: Coping with nonlinearity and coupled processes using a data-driven approach
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This work aims to explore the relationship between soil physical-chemical properties and relief morphometry, and quantifying these relationships to build conceptual and predictive models. Self-organizing maps and Geographic Information Systems modeling are here used to investigate nonlinear correlations associated with chemical and physical denudation; which are factors connected with hydrological phenomena and soil evolution. Three study cases are presented: soil chemical weathering within the limits of the Parana State, southern Brazil (22 variables and 304 samples), physical transport of sediments in the alkaline intrusive complex of Poços de Caldas,&#10;southeastern Brazil (9 variables and 29 samples), and hydrochemistry of Serra Geral aquifers also in the Parana State (27 variables and 976 samples). The method combining stochastic simulation and data mining allows exploring the relationships between topography, soil texture and soil geochemistry. In the Parana State, higher regions and areas with convex morphometry shows, respectively, higher and lower denudation rates of mobile (e.g., Ca) and less mobile (e.g., Al) elements. The same pattern is observed for soil particle size. In this case, high proportion of sand is found in highlands and convex areas inside the basin, and high clay content, with low hydraulic conductivity, occurs in convex regions, near drainage channels. The spatial behavior of the Serra Geral aquifer’s hydrochemistry pointed out to areas with potential connectivity with the Guarani aquifer system, recent recharge areas, and long-standing&#10;waters. Predictive, unbiased models are built for soil properties on the premise that weathering and morphology are related through a two-way dependent process, where the physical and chemical denudation delineates the elevations of the land surface, and terrain morphometry is a factor that characterizes the physical-chemical conditions of the soil.

PESQUISA-E-DESENVOLVIMENTO.NOME-ORGAO: Crustal Gephysics and Geochemistry Science Center

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-ORGAO: Division of Earth and Ecosystem Sciences

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Integrated Desert Terrain Forecasting for Military Operations
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Deserts are, and will continue to be, strategic sites for military operations. Military success in desert conditions requires familiarity with these environments, as well as appropriate training and testing in locations that are characterized by rapidly changing surface conditions and climatic extremes, ranging from dust storm and brownout generation to terrain-induced mobility and detection hazard.&#10;The ultimate goal of this multi-year initiative is to develop an integrated, predictive tool for forecasting desert terrain conditions (soils, vegetation cover, landscape form, dust emission potential) to support military activities. Project results have lead to the development of a geographic information system (GIS) platform to predict essential surface and subsurface terrain conditions through the integration of data on the spatial distribution, age and geology of desert landforms. The GIS platform provides an expert-based prediction system, linking surface observables to subsurface conditions over a wide range of scales in near real-time by incorporating information from satellite and unmanned aerial remote-sensing technology.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Deserts are, and will continue to be, strategic sites for military operations. Military success in desert conditions requires familiarity with these environments, as well as appropriate training and testing in locations that are characterized by rapidly changing surface conditions and climatic extremes, ranging from dust storm and brownout generation to terrain-induced mobility and detection hazard.&#10;The ultimate goal of this multi-year initiative is to develop an integrated, predictive tool for forecasting desert terrain conditions (soils, vegetation cover, landscape form, dust emission potential) to support military activities. Project results have lead to the development of a geographic information system (GIS) platform to predict essential surface and subsurface terrain conditions through the integration of data on the spatial distribution, age and geology of desert landforms. The GIS platform provides an expert-based prediction system, linking surface observables to subsurface conditions over a wide range of scales in near real-time by incorporating information from satellite and unmanned aerial remote-sensing technology.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Integrated Desert Terrain Forecasting for Military Operations

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Intergração de dados multisensor e espectroscopia de reflectância aplicados ao mapeamento de alvos estratégicos da agricultura tropical
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: A intensa demanda mundial por alimento, aliada a questões ambientais de uso sustentável dos recursos naturais, delineiam um quadro de busca pela máxima eficiência na produtividade agrícola, o que envolve maior eficácia no monitoramento das áreas de cultivo. Ferramentas analíticas capazes de abarcar variação amostral e abrangência territorial representam um custo elevado de operação e replicação dos resultados. O sensoriamento remoto tem se mostrado ferramenta eficiente para o mapeamento/monitoramento de áreas agrícolas, sobretudo no acompanhamento de safras, déficit hídrico e medidas de biomassa, obtendo resultados sinópticos e espaciais extremamente relevantes porém, encontra-se ainda em desenvolvimento em termos da exploração de suas propriedades de quantificação e qualificação.&#10;&#10;Este projeto faz uso do sensoriamento remoto, suas técnicas e sensores de última geração, para a exploração integral da radiação eletromagnética em diferentes comprimentos de onda como método analítico auxiliar de baixo custo e não destrutivo para a estimativa de parâmetros biofísicos de alvos relacionados à agricultura tropical, como a soja e, por sua intrínseca relação com os sistemas ambientais e de cultivo, aos solos. Como estratégia de abordagem, serão utilizados métodos de espectroscopia de reflectância consorciados com diferentes sensores imageadores aerotransportados e orbitais.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Intergração de dados multisensor e espectroscopia de reflectância aplicados ao mapeamento de alvos estratégicos da agricultura tropical

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: A New Integrated Catchment-Channel Erosion Model to Underpin Cost Efficient Flood Response Management, Sediment Load Reduction to the Great Barrier Reef and Moreton Bay, and Improvements to Brisbane's Drinking Water Quality
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This project will link two major NRM programs (SEQ Healthy Waterways Partnership and Reef Rescue) and develop a new catchment scale channel erosion model for Queensland Rivers, building on the process understanding captured in an existing local scale bank erosion model - the Bank-Stability and Toe-Erosion Model (BSTEM). We will incorporate the effects of locaI riparian vegetation, then integrate BSTEM with the industry standard 1D hydraulic and sediment transport model HEC-RAS. Data on root characteristics of Australian riparian vegetation will be incorporated into the root-reinforcement sub-model RipRoot to extend the species “library” within BSTEM. We will then test and apply the integrated model in three catchments- the Brisbane River; the O'Connell River in the MacKay Whitsunday region; and the Normanby River in Cape York. This will involve an evaluation of channel erosion, sediment transport and downstream delivery within the in the three catchments. Finally, the combined HEC-RAS/BSTEM model will be interfaced with a sediment budget model being used in each of the basins to allow for a fully integrated modeling framework for determining magnitudes and sources of sediment.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: This project will link two major NRM programs (SEQ Healthy Waterways Partnership and Reef Rescue) and develop a new catchment scale channel erosion model for Queensland Rivers, building on the process understanding captured in an existing local scale bank erosion model - the Bank-Stability and Toe-Erosion Model (BSTEM). We will incorporate the effects of locaI riparian vegetation, then integrate BSTEM with the industry standard 1D hydraulic and sediment transport model HEC-RAS. Data on root characteristics of Australian riparian vegetation will be incorporated into the root-reinforcement sub-model RipRoot to extend the species “library” within BSTEM. We will then test and apply the integrated model in three catchments- the Brisbane River; the O'Connell River in the MacKay Whitsunday region; and the Normanby River in Cape York. This will involve an evaluation of channel erosion, sediment transport and downstream delivery within the in the three catchments. Finally, the combined HEC-RAS/BSTEM model will be interfaced with a sediment budget model being used in each of the basins to allow for a fully integrated modeling framework for determining magnitudes and sources of sediment.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: A New Integrated Catchment-Channel Erosion Model to Underpin Cost Efficient Flood Response Management, Sediment Load Reduction to the Great Barrier Reef and Moreton Bay, and Improvements to Brisbane's Drinking Water Quality

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Upper Hunter Geomorphic Assessment: Selected Reaches of the Hunter and Pages Rivers
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Engineered Log Jams (ELJs) ELJs were first utilised as a river management technique in the Williams River in 2000 as part of a large scale experiment carried out in collaboration with the then Hunter CMA and the Hunter soil services river works crew. Following the success if these first experimental trials, this technique has now become part of the standard tool kit used for river management works throughout the Hunter and indeed around the country and internationally. The design guideline for wood reintroduction that was developed as a result of this research has become the standard for this technique in Australia. There had been some “drift” in structure design and construction methods over time in the Hunter, and that the more recently constructed structures were potentially less effective than some of the earlier ones. It was also apparent that as time had gone on the effectiveness of some structures in meeting with the original objectives had diminished. Given these concerns, it is important to assess whether some recalibration of the overall objectives of rehabilitation efforts is required. This document set out, with varying levels of detail, a three tiered rehabilitation plan of this section of the Hunter River set within an overarching rehabilitation objective. Hence, it is extremely timely to review those objectives, particularly in light of the fact that a broad range of research has now been published on the Upper Hunter River, in the wake of the Upper Hunter River Rehabilitation Initiative (UHRRI). The UHRRI related literature and a number of other post- UHRRI studies will form of the core of the literature review. This Hunter-specific literature will also be placed in the context of the broader river restoration/rehabilitation literature, both at the national and international level. The scope of that project precluded a thorough assessment of the broader rehabilitation objectives of the UHRRI reach. As such, in this project we will thoroughly reassess the UHRRI objectives and the associated rehabilitation works undertaken in this 10km section of the upper Hunter River, as well as the 5km reach between Bengalla Bridge and Muswellbrook. Following the review and update of the rehabilitation objectives for the UHRRI reach and the Aberdeen to Muswellbrook reach, the section of the Hunter and lower Pages River upstream of Aberdeen will analysed, in the light of the different channel and valley scale boundary conditions in these reaches (i.e. River Styles).
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The Upper Hunter Geomorphic Assessment: Selected Reaches of the Hunter and Pages Rivers

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Bank Erosion in the Upper Brisbane River: Prioritising management Options at the Burrows and Weildons Properties
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Previous research in the upper Brisbane River has highlighted that bank erosion is a key sediment source to Lake Wivenhoe, however, as pointed out by Shellberg and Brooks (2007), these catchment scale sediment budget and tracing exercises are at scale that is too coarse for management planning. This point is made more starkly from an analysis undertaken as part of this study, which compares the observed erosion rates, with the rates predicted by the previous SedNet modeling for the same reach. SedNet model has very poor predictive power at a resolution that is useful for designing a management strategy, explaining only 13.5% of the variability in bank erosion at the 1km reach scale.&#10;Sediment tracing studies using fallout radionuclides, have confirmed that the dominant source of sediment entering Lake Wivenhoe is channel erosion, and 50% of this sediment was shown to be sourced from the Esk Formation geology, through which the Upper Brisbane flows. A large flood in 2011, and subsequent flood in 2013, have further highlighted the threat posed by bank erosion to SE Qld’s primary water storage reservoir, as well as to riparian landholders through the loss of valuable alluvial land. In this study we use repeat aerial LiDAR surveys collected 10 years apart, to provide a much more robust analysis of the extent of bank erosion that has occurred in the upper Brisbane River. Analysis of a range of geomorphic, hydrologic and hydraulic variables is then undertaken to explain the spatial variability of observed erosion – which can then inform analysis of the likelihood of the erosion continuing at any one site.

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: South East Queensland Bulk Water Supply Authority

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Spatial hybrid modelling of riverbank erosion on tropical rivers: integrating soil geotechnical properties and morphometric parameters derived from repeated LiDAR
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Catchment-scale sediment budget models are used worldwide to target rehabilitation activities aimed at reducing erosion and improving water quality. These models aim to identify the major sediment and nutrient sources within a catchment to target rehabilitation action. Currently the weakest component of these models is the prediction of riverbank and channel erosion, and yet this is the focus of most river management activities (e.g. riparian re-vegetation, fencing and other channel stabilization activities). Independent element tracing techniques show that riverbank and alluvial gully erosion are the dominant source of sediment in most tropical river systems. Yet, both these processes are currently poorly parameterized in models used for targeting management action. This project aims to advance in the riverbank erosion modelling process and the estimation of soil geotechnical parameters using machine learning methods. We will develop a methodology using self-organizing maps to integrate extensive field sampling collected across three basins in the state of Queensland, expert knowledge geomorphic mapping, terrain morphometry and soil erosion rates calculated from repeated LiDAR to build a predicting model of riverbank erosion, using Monte Carlo simulation to evaluate model uncertainty. I believe that this novel framework will prove to be important in addressing current issues of terrain relief and soil-water interaction models that are commonly used in studies of water supply, agricultural suitability, flood risk assessment, mass movement hazards and land occupation near rivers.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Spatial hybrid modelling of riverbank erosion on tropical rivers: integrating soil geotechnical properties and morphometric parameters derived from repeated LiDAR

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: A geostatistics-machine learning hybrid approach for parameter estimation in hydrogeological models
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Field datasets characterizing groundwater are oftentimes scarce and expensive to collect. Remote sensing is an alternative for an exploratory characterization of groundwater where none currently exist. The reasoning of using remote sensing lies in quantifying the relationship of surface processes and features, such as surface geology, geormorphic units, soil hydraulic properties, surface runoff, and other potential explanatory variables with groundwater properties. Through these connections it is possible to quantify some parameters necessary for numerical modeling, or for surface mapping of key variables for water resources management decisions. For instance, mapping areas of high hydraulic conductivity across aquifer recharge areas would be essential to determine areas under risk of aquifer contamination. Another problem is, when available, groundwater field measurements can be inconsistent, with missing variables or different levels of precision. This poses a crucial issue as most of the parametric multivariate methods require a complete dataset to calculate eigenvalues and eigenvectors in order to obtain a covariance matrix. An approach to solve this problem are imputation methods that estimate missing values in multivariate datasets based on the correlations calculated from complete subsets. However, these methods are essentially still linear approaches; an alternative to cope with such sparse, noisy datasets are machine learning methods. This works has two main objectives; first, parameters for groundwater models will be measured through field tests (geoelectric and permeameters) and laboratory analysis (soil and water), in order to feed groundwater numerical models across key region in Colombia; next such parameters will be upscaled using a machine learning-geostatistics, hybrid approach to be used as pilot points in inverse modeling, additionally, these predicted values will be evaluated through a stochastic bootstrap method; second, from the results of the previous step a spatialized model will be built with respective uncertainty evaluation. It is expected that the methodology developed and the results obtained in this work will create a background and a framework that will support new externally funded projects.
